net.sourceforge.waters.model.expr

Class ExpressionParser

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.sourceforge.waters.model.expr.ExpressionParser

  • public class ExpressionParser
extends Object

    The expression parser.

    The expression parser can produce expression objects (SimpleExpressionProxy) from textual representations. It is therefore used to analyse all user input for events, ranges, aliases, etc.

    In order to translate a string into an expression, an ExpressionParser object must be created first. The following code can be used to parse a string called text.

       final ModuleProxyFactory factory = ModuleElementFactory.getInstance();
   final OperatorTable optable = CompilerOperatorTable.getInstance();
   final ExpressionParser parser = new ExpressionParser(ModuleProxyFactory,OperatorTable)(factory, optable);
   try {
     expr = parser.parse(text);
   } catch (final ParseException exception) {
     // an error has occurred ...
     ...
   }

    The parser includes simple type checking functionality, which works correctly as long as the evaluation context is not required. For example, the type of an expression 1 + 3 can be accurately identified as integer. The type of an identifier such as ev2, however, remains unknown because names may be bound to different values depending on the context in which they are evaluated.

    Type checking is performed automatically on subterms of expressions. For example, it is checked whether the arguments of an addition expression can be integers. In addition, the parser can be instructed to check the expected type of an expression to be parsed by passing it a type mask. To check whether an expression may be an integer or an atom, e.g., the following code can be used.

       expr = parser.parse
     (text, Operator.TYPE_INT | Operator.TYPE_ATOM);
    Author:
    Robi Malik

      • parse

        public SimpleExpressionProxy parse(String input,
                                   int mask)
                            throws ParseException
        Parses a string into an expression and performs simple type checking.
        Parameters:
        input - The string to be parsed.
        mask - A bit mask identifying the expected type of the evaluated expression, using the type constants Operator.TYPE_INT, Operator.TYPE_ATOM, Operator.TYPE_RANGE, and Operator.TYPE_NAME.
        Throws:
        ParseException - to indicate that the string could not be parsed because of some syntax error.

      • parse

        public SimpleExpressionProxy parse(Reader reader,
                                   int mask)
                            throws IOException,
                                   ParseException
        Parses an expression from an input stream. This method tries to read the entire stream and produce an expression out of it. It is an error if the stream contains extra characters at the end.
        Parameters:
        reader - A reader providing input from a stream.
        mask - A bit mask identifying the expected type of the evaluated expression, using the type constants Operator.TYPE_INT, Operator.TYPE_ATOM, Operator.TYPE_RANGE, and Operator.TYPE_NAME.
        Throws:
        ParseException - to indicate that the input could not be parsed because of some syntax error.
        IOException - to indicate that reading from the input stream has failed.

      • parse

        public SimpleExpressionProxy parse(Reader reader,
                                   int mask,
                                   String input)
                            throws IOException,
                                   ParseException
        Parses an expression from an input stream. This method tries to read the entire stream and produce an expression out of it. It is an error if the stream contains extra characters at the end.
        Parameters:
        reader - A reader providing input from a stream.
        mask - A bit mask identifying the expected type of the evaluated expression, using the type constants Operator.TYPE_INT, Operator.TYPE_ATOM, Operator.TYPE_RANGE, and Operator.TYPE_NAME.
        input - The original text of the expression. If non-null, this string is provided as (optional) rendering text to the parsed expression.
        Throws:
        ParseException - to indicate that the input could not be parsed because of some syntax error.
        IOException - to indicate that reading from the input stream has failed.

      • isOperatorCharacter

        public boolean isOperatorCharacter(int ch)
        Checks whether a character represents an operator character.
        Parameters:
        ch - The character to be checked.
        Returns:
        true if the given character can be used in a Waters operator.

      • isSeparatorCharacter

        public boolean isSeparatorCharacter(int ch)
        Checks whether a character represents a separator character.
        Parameters:
        ch - The character to be checked.
        Returns:
        true if the given character can be used as a special, or separator, character in a Waters expression.

      • isExpressionCharacter

        public boolean isExpressionCharacter(int ch)
        Checks whether a character is an expression character.
        Parameters:
        ch - The character to be checked.
        Returns:
        true if the given character can occur somewhere in a syntactically correct expression.
